His son, Dale, tells me that he is proud to have served and to have a father who heroically served. I agree, and I salute Mr. Dorinski and his son for their service to our country.

One of his sons went on to serve in the U.S. Army Reserve during the Vietnam War and later wrote a book based on his father‚Äôs time in the Pacific, inspiring more people to live a life of service for their communities and their country.
His story, however, does not end there. Mr. Dorinski‚Äôs service profoundly influenced his four children, teaching them self-reliance, confidence, hard work and the value of an education.
A year after his return, he married the love of his life, and together they raised three sons and a daughter. Mr. Dorinski passed away in 2012.

Following the heroic victory in the war, however, tragedy struck at home when his mother passed away shortly after his return.  As a young man in his early 20s, he learned that life consists of battles and you win some and lose some.
During the Battle of the Philippine Sea and the Mariana Campaign, the destroyer ship played a role in the American victory, enduring the force attacks and kamikazes from the Japanese.

Today‚Äôs #veteran spotlight is Mr. Walter Dorinski, who served in the United States from 1943 to 1946 at the height of World War II.  As a radioman, he was stationed in the USS Wilson, patrolling the Pacific Ocean. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FFegGjMXsAEJgDE.jpg
